channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PIG-3457] Provide backward compatibility for PigStatsUtil and JobStats
item.description:
PIG-3419 restructured PigStatsUtil which break downstream projects such as Oozie. Oozie uses PigStatsUtil.

{HDFS_BYTES_WRITTEN, MAP_INPUT_RECORDS, MAP_OUTPUT_RECORDS, REDUCE_INPUT_RECORDS, REDUCE_OUTPUT_RECORDS}

. We need to provide a backward compatible way.
item.summary: Provide backward compatibility for PigStatsUtil and JobStats

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Checked both JobStats, PigStatsUtil are marked as Public Evolving. We can change but need to keep backward compatibility for several releases.
Daniel Dai, isn't your patch ready to commit? It looks good to me.

Daniel,
Oozie only seems to be using the constants from PigStatsUtil. But the patch seems to be doing lot more and I am not able to easily follow. Can you put the patch in review board ?

I think there are 2 changes:

  1. Changes JobStats to JobStatsBase and PigStatsUtil to PigStatsUtilBase. This requires many changes in many places where JobStats and PigStatsUtil are used.
  2. Adds dummy classes JobStats and PigStatsUtil that extends MRJobStats and MRPigStatsUtil respectively, so Oozie still can work without changing PigStatsUtil to MRPigStatsUtil.

Ok. PigStatsUtil extends MRPigStatsUtil so that it still has those public constants.

Few minor comments:
1) Can we name it PigStatsBase and get rid of Util?
2) Can we mark both the new classes as Evolving?

Retracting comment 1. PigStatsBase will be confused with PigStats.

Created a jira in Oozie to get rid of the references to the constant.

Thanks Cheolsoo Park, you explained the patch very well.

Rohini Palaniswamy, for your comment:

1) Can we name it PigStatsBase and get rid of Util?

I feel that is more confusing, it gives the impression PigStats extends PigStatsBase. However, it is a separate family: PigStatsUtilBase -> MRPigStatsUtil -> PigStatsUtil

2) Can we mark both the new classes as Evolving?

I think we will have a follow up for PIG-3419 to remark all new interfaces. But if you want me to mark the affected classes in this patch, I can also do that.
Agree with 1. Already retracted that comment . Cheolsoo already committed PIG-3464. So if we can mark it evolving in this patch and then commit it, it would be good.
Reattached the patch with the marking.
Patch committed to trunk.
The original patch does not fix Oozie. Provide another remedy.
PIG-3457-4.patch fixed unit test failures.

Does the PPNL need to be an interface? This jira shows how annoying/fragile it is to have an interface which a number of non-Pig projects depend on and that will likely be modified/extended in the future.

It seems like a base class that would extend the existing PPNL interface and then provide no-op implementations for all methods would be easier to work with and extend in the future.

Agree, abstract class would be better if we start over again.

However, the issue here is different. PIG-3419 change the meaning of JobStats we used to communicate the Pig execution status in PigProgressNotificationListener API and PigStats API. It is down-scoped and methods such as getNumberMaps etc are removed. It will affect the downstream projects no matter PigProgressNotificationListener is an interface or a class. This Jira is to bring the old JobStats back (also PigStatsUtil, but that is less involved compare to JobStats).

Sorry, I didn't mean the change needs to be part of this jira (the patch committed previously in this jira was just a good example of the pain of changing the PPNL interface). I could open a new jira and get a patch up for it if it has support.

I can see the PPNL changing regularly and I think the sooner we make that easier the better. For example in the illustrate patch I'd like to get up next week I have new events that I'd like to get into the PPNL.
Sure, we can open a ticket and get opinion from others, especially those who rely on PPNL.

PIG-3457-5.patch is ready for review.

Bring PigStats/PPNL interface back. Downstream projects will get a JobStats object which has all the methods as before. Existing code might need to recompile, but there should be no code change.

Thank you Daniel for taking care of this. Two questions:
1) Can we commit this only to branch-0.12? We don't need to carry this on in 0.13, do we?
2) I don't seem to understand why it's necessary for JobStats class to have the private MRJobStats member while it extends MRJobStats. Can you help me to understand this?

 public class JobStats extends MRJobStats {
+    MRJobStats jobStats;
     public JobStats(String name, JobGraph plan) {
         super(name, plan);
     }
+    public JobStats(MRJobStats mrJobStats) {
+        super(mrJobStats.getName(), (JobGraph)mrJobStats.getPlan());
+        this.jobStats = mrJobStats;
+    }
+    
+    @Override
+    public JobState getState() { return jobStats.getState(); }
...

Thanks for looking into it. Here is my answer:
1. The goal is to provide a backward compatible way for PPNL/PigStats in both 0.12/0.13. The patch provide a hack to achieve it, I am also open to explore other solutions. So the answer is depends, but we need to provide backward compatibility.

2. What I did here is to provide a JobStats copy of MRJobStats. PigStats.JobGraph still have a MRJobStats plan internally. When we present to user, we want user to get JobStats instead. Since we cannot upcast an object in Java, so I create a new JobStats object and wrap the MRJobStats object. Alternatively, I can create a new JobStats object, and copy every fields of MRJobStats over. However, many fields in MRJobStats is marked private.

I thought that we could provide backward compatibility in 0.12 only - i.e. deprecating JobStats in 0.12 and deleting it in 0.13. I don't know whether it's acceptable to others though.

All the complexity seems to come from exposing JobStats to users in many public interfaces. So if we can ask downstream projects to update their code before 0.13, we can move on with whatever fix works for now. But sounds like you want to keep backward compatibility in both 0.12 and 0.13...

My personal opinion is, changing PigStats seems to be too intrusive. PPNL probably Ok, since we know there is only a few downstream projects. But I imagine PigRunner.run() would be used extensively, and it might affect a large user base. How do you think?

Writing tools that have to support different versions of the same Java interface is a pain. I think there will be tools (Mortar and Lipstick at least) that will want to support 0.12 and 0.13 at the same time they're still supporting at least 0.11.

Given that the PPNL is very 'public facing' I think ideally we'd actually have a deprecation path that doesn't cause compile time problems.

I think something like:

  • Leave PPNL in its current state. Deprecate methods w/ JobStats as a parameter
  • Add BasePPNL which implements PPNL. Have it offer new methods w/ JobStatsBase as the parameter and offer no-op implementations
  • Change ScriptState to allow registering both PPNLs and BasePPNLs. New events will only be emitted to BasePPNLs.

I think this would let 3rd party tools take advantage of new methods in the PPNL while still easily working with older versions of Pig.

Daniel Dai, I have been thinking about this over the weekend. Your patch totally fixes backward incompatibility, but I don't think it solves the fundamental issue though. Like Jeremy Karn says, we need to provide a depreciation path. If we don't provide new methods with new types, users cannot upgrade their code, so it will be broken again when we remove deprecated types in the future.

But the problem is that we cannot do what Jeremy Karn suggests in PigRunner because PigStats is the return type of PigRunner.run(), and we cannot overload a method with different return type. We can either use different method names or different java packages. If we do the latter, we can keep two versions of classes for JobStats, PigStats, PigRunner, PigServer, etc in 0.12/0.13 and retire deprecated ones in 0.14.

I briefly experimented with java packages. Basically, I brought back all the old classes (JobStats, PigStats, ScriptState, etc) to "org.apache.pig" and moved everything else to a new package called "org.apache.pig.v1". The downside of this is that we will end up with a lot of duplicate code (even though it's temporary). The upside is that all the deprecated classes will be isolated under separate packages and deleted all together in the future. I am not sure whether this is a good idea or not.
PIG-3419 is reverted in 0.12.
Patch reverted since PIG-3457-2.patch alone does not provide backward compatibility. And we are still exploring a better way to provide backward compatibility.
